newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Albania takes steps to flatten pyramid schemes.
newsitem.headline: Albania takes steps to flatten pyramid schemes.

text.p: The Albanian government decided on Tuesday to form a commission to investigate the get-rich-quick investment schemes that have ruined thousands of small investors and set off a rash of street protests.
Hundreds of out-of-pocket Albanians converged on pyramid investment offices in Tirana on Tuesday, desperate to retrieve their savings.

Over the weekend, thousands of investors staged demonstrations in Tirana and other major cities in this impoverished Balkan nation, blaming President Sali Berisha's right-wing government for doing too little to regulate a post-communist explosion of unsound financial schemes.
Berisha vowed last Saturday to crack down on the schemes and warned the opposition against exploiting the ire among investors to try to destabilise the state.
Radio Tirana reported that a special government commission would evaluate the actual extent of lending to such schemes and recomment measures to help secure investors' money.

Prime Minister Aleksander Meksi said the government would compile a law based on the commission's findings and would present it to parliament by Monday to bring a halt to pyramid-style borrowing schemes.
"With this law we aim at giving a global solution for each case, so that everyone has the same compensation from the division of the properties of these companies," Meksi told Albanian television.
Pyramid schemes burgeoned in Europe's poorest country after the fall of communism in 1990, luring thousands of Albanians into selling their homes, land and livestock with promises of big returns.
Three pyramid schemes have failed so far, leaving thousands out of pocket. Four more have suspended payments to investors.
The Albanian government on Thursday ordered the seizure of 25.5 billion leks ($255 million) deposited by such schemes in state-owned banks.
Last week's demonstrations were broken up by the police and newspapers reported scores of arrests. Western diplomats in Tirana said they were watching developments with concern.

"The government should find a way out not only to calm people but to help them get back at least to last year's financial situation. Otherwise it will have a lot of social problems," said one diplomat, who declined to be named.
